title.native: ファイ・ブレイン 神のパズル

description:
Kaito Daimon would be a completely average high school student except for one thing: he's a 'demon' at solving puzzles. Kaito is so brilliant, in fact, that when he's asked to take some 'special' tests of his unique ability, he immediately suspects that the test itself is a test. Kaito suddenly finds himself caught up in a lethal Philosopher's Puzzle made by the sinister group POG, a murderous maze of trap upon trap, where failing to solve the secret correctly will result in death! Fortunately, Kaito's skills prove up to the first test, both for himself and his childhood friend Nanoha, who is also caught up in the deadly scheme. But now that he has been designated as a Solver, he is pulled into a new life where he must travel the world with other Solvers, attempting to solve the latest deadly riddles left by POG. There's a new conundrum around every corner and each deception could lead to death, but once a riddle has been posed, you can count on Kaito to unfold, unravel and unlock it!

(Source: Sentai Filmworks)
synonyms: Phi Φ Brain: Kami no Puzzle

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Orphan
tags.description: Prominently features a character that is an orphan.

tags.name: Death Game
tags.description: Features characters participating in a game, where failure results in death.

tags.name: Card Battle
tags.description: Centers around individuals competing in card games.

tags.name: Acting
tags.description: Centers around actors or the acting industry.

tags.name: Memory Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features a character(s) who has had their memories altered.

tags.name: Dissociative Identities
tags.description: A case where one or more people share the same body.

tags.name: Episodic
tags.description: Features story arcs that are loosely tied or lack an overarching plot.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Adoption
tags.description: Features a character who has been adopted by someone who is neither of their biological parents.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: Primarily Teen Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of teen characters.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Foreign
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a country outside the country of origin.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: School
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a primary or secondary educational institution.

tags.name: Crossdressing
tags.description: Prominently features a character dressing up as the opposite sex.

tags.name: Idol
tags.description: Centers around the life and activities of an idol.

tags.name: Motorcycles
tags.description: Prominently features the use of motorcycles.

tags.name: Achromatic
tags.description: Contains animation that is primarily done in black and white.

tags.name: Femboy
tags.description: Features a boy who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of girls.

ルーク・盤城・クロスフィールド

node.description:
[Website](http://www.yatate.net/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yatate_hajime) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/矢立肇) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hajime_Yatate)

Hajime Yatate is a collective pseudonym for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/)'s staff.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/satojumichi) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/佐藤順一)

Junichi Satou is a Japanese anime director, best known for working on shoujo-based anime and in the magical girl genre. He was formerly associated with [TYO Animations](https://anilist.co/studio/333/), formerly known as [Hal Film Maker](https://anilist.co/studio/34/).

Satou’s first major work was directing the first, and a portion of the second season of [Sailor Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/530/) for [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/), after which he handed the position over to [Kunihiko Ikuhara](https://anilist.co/staff/100082/), although he continued to storyboard and direct episodes for the later seasons. Satou later went on to co-direct [Ojamajo Doremi](https://anilist.co/anime/350/) alongside [Takuya Igarashi](https://anilist.co/staff/105087/), as well as the critically acclaimed [Princess Tutu](https://anilist.co/anime/721/). Satou served as chief director for long-runner [Sgt. Frog](https://anilist.co/anime/516/), and in recent years has become more known for his iyashikei works such as [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477/) and [Tamayura](https://anilist.co/anime/9055/).

He's married to [Yasuno Satou](https://anilist.co/staff/144094/).

(Source: Wikipedia)
_Note: Not to be confused with the [voice actress](https://anilist.co/staff/197781/)._
Also is a writer, producer and director for ADV Films and Robotboy Films.
Made his directorial debut with [Katekyou Hitman Reborn!](https://anilist.co/anime/1604/), in which he storyboarded half of the episodes.
Shinichi Omata is a Japanese director, storyboard artist, and former producer best known for directing Showa Genroku Rakugo Shinju (2016) and Kaguya-sama: Love is War (2019).
